It's not just American patriotism that should be aroused by those images. There were people from other countries that died in the attacks. We should all  be incensed by the random killings of innocent people everywhere on the planet. People of every nation represented in the list of victims should be incensed and driven toward retaliation against the terrorism that brings this kind of grief to the world.
 
 If we could succeed in killing all of the gutless terrorist rats, the world would be a much better place. Their blood  needs to be spilled, not that of innocent children.
 
 That is not likely to happen, but a rejuvenation of patriotism, American or other, is not going to hurt.
 
 A country without patriotism is just a place to exist. A country full of patriotism is a place to live.
 
 Since patriotism is basically an emotional thing, there's not much wrong with being melodramatic in drumming it up. The quotes by our forefathers are somewhat dramatically put because they had no images to use, other than what they could create in the minds of those who heard them speak. The horror of the day and the grief of the survivors is quite evident in the pictures shown. There's hardly any other way to describe it fully.
 
 Of course, there will always be those insensitive people who think grief should not be shared. I will go to my grave wondering why.

So did I and I can say that I DO agree with this aproach.

 
 
 To me, it seems like a guilt-injecting, sympathy arousing ploy to empty pockets. I'm all for charity to the victims, but this is not a good approach, in my opinion. When watching this flash video I felt what was insinuated is that I was somehow responsible for this tragedy. I didn't like that feeling, therefore, I condemn this type of approach.
 I've also always felt it's wrong to show the hordes of people leaping to their death, especially for this kind of thing. That seems to me like it's taking advantage of someone else's misfortunes. The person in my family who died in this tragedy leapt to this death. I think any of these photos showing victims leaping to their deaths should be exempt from this kind of flash video. It's insensitive and it's there for no other reason but to invoke feelings of sorrow and pity and to then empty one's pockets. 
 Wrong approach for this kind of thing. Very wrong.

 While it's not to my personal taste, and I retain my healty cinicsm over the motives, I don't really see anything wrong with the film at all.

The film is appropriate, in my opinion.
 
 In every major case of national REACTION to an event such as 911, there has been a theame of "Remember the...." (Maine, Alamo, Boston Massacre, ect.). Therefore, the movie is to be expected. 
 
 In my opinion, we NEED to be reminded! The US has been attacked repeatedly by terrorists! (WTC #1, Embasy in Nirobi (sp?), Embasy in Kenya, Kaioushi (sounds like) Towers in Saudi Arabia, and the USS Cole were all attacks on the US before 911.)
 
 The war in Iraq IS a part of the open war that has been waged upon us.  The Truth of Battle
 
 "There were young knights among them who had never been present at a stricken field. Some could not look upon it, some could not speak. They held themselves apart from the others who were cutting down prisoners at my lord's orders, for the prisoners were a body too numerous to be guarded by those of us who were left. 
 
 Then jean de rye, an aged knight of burgundy who had been sore wounded in the fight, rode up to the group of young knights and said: "are ye maidens with your downcast eyes? Look well upon it. See all of it. Close your eyes to nothing. For the battle is fought to be won, and this is what happens if you lose."

 1. 2 word rant in response to a post can come across as dismissive and hostile. 
 
 2. I never called you a liberal I just suggested that you fall somewhere to the left of me.
 
 3. I answered you on how I thought you politisized the issue. Just because you disagree with me does not mean I am "dodging" you (also hostile in some circles)
 
 4. Rambling indicates a long winded speach that has many tangents and no coherent argument. I guess comparing my responses to a 2 word rant can be considered rambling if we are simply counting words.
 
 rambling
 
 adj 1: (of e.g. speech and writing) tending to depart from the main point or cover a wide range of subjects; "amusingly digressive with satirical thrusts at women's fashions among other things"; "a rambling discursive book"; "his excursive remarks"; "a rambling speech about this and that" [syn: digressive, discursive, excursive] 2: of a path e.g.; "meandering streams"; "rambling forest paths"; "the river followed its wandering course"; "a winding country road" [syn: meandering(a), wandering(a), winding]
 
 5. Add the rambling to the "come up with a rational argument" indicating my irationalality (is that a word?) and we begin to see a pattern of attacking my abilities to hang with the intellectuals such as yourself. 
 
 6. Instead of challenging me on how I came to the conclusion that I fall "somewhere" to the Right of you why don't you explain your positions instead of calling my arguments irrational and debating me instead of the topic?

While this was a reminder of the 9-11 event,it's also a reminder that we didn't concentrate all our resources into capturing or killing the people who masterminded it.I don't think any of us can truly forget the event,but we certainally got sidetracked.IMO

 
 Did we ever get sidetracked. While I consider the event memorable and cause for like retaliation against Bin Laden, using it to solicit donations for victims already amply compensated in a financial manner seems pretty cheesy. Using patriotism to drag in even more money seems even cheesier. 
 
 Terrorist activity being waged against us, including events before 9/11, are a direct result of our foreign policy regarding Israel and Mideast oil interests. I find it difficult to invoke patriotism in support of issues we've created out of self-interest, much less donate to victims of our own policies of aggression.
 
 I'm not making a political statement, most wars have been fought over control of natural resources, but I'll let others donate to victims of situations we create and wave the flag over to garner public support.

 rambling is not insulting, it means exactly what the definition you put up states, "rambling
 
 adj 1: (of e.g. speech and writing) tending to depart from the main point "
 
 I used it in context to you not answering the question, which you claimed to have answered. I went and reviewed the posts and found no such response. 
 In review, I apologize, you did not call me liberal, you indicated that I was anti-american. 
 Since when has saying someone is dodging a question been hostile? I have never seen anyone banned for saying someone is dodging a question. 
 
 Again, if I came across as hostile in my "2 word rant" I did not intend to, but I did intend to be dismissive, because I did not have a great appreciation for that particular video. 
 As to my own personal, political outlook am more in line with a Libertarian philosophy than either of the two major parties, but I do disagree with Libs on some issues too <lol I have a tough time finding any particular outlook to be completely satisfactory< but there are other threads which I espouse my political views, but I don't want to hijack this thread for a politcal theory debate.
 I admit that the rational argument statement, while not directly insulting, could be construed in a slightly hostile manner, so I rescind in and replace it with an "elaboration on your argument". (but just FYI, indicating that someone is being rational does not question their intelligence, I know plenty of irrational, intelligent people) emoticon_xbouncer
